Identifying Characteristics: Usually light brown or tawny with pronounced black spots on the back, sides and head
Spots are often surrounded with reddish halo, along with reddish spots on the sides
Biology: Spawn in the fall, usually October or November
Spawn primarily is streams, selecting coarse rubble bottom substrates in riffle areas
Males defend their chosen territories against the intrusion of rival males prior to active spawning
Young hatch out the following spring and normally spend the first two to three years of life in the parent stream feeding on insects and other minute animal life
Able to withstand higher water temperatures that Brook Trout
Size: average size is 14-20 inches and 1-2 pounds, but may occasionally reach 10 pounds
May live to be 20 years old
Diet: Larger brown trout may prey upon small fish
Range: Native Range: Northern Europe, Asia and North Africa
Introduced Range: Worldwide, including North and South America, Australasia, Asia, and South and East Africa.
As in many introduced areas, Maineâ€™s brown trout have established self-sustaining, wild populations
One of the first introductions of brown trout in the United States was in Branch Lake, Ellsworth, Maine, in 1885
